incorporation_agency: Texas Secretary of State - Corporations Section
charitable_registration_agency: Texas Attorney General - Charitable Trusts Section
exemption_threshold_note: Organizations with gross receipts under $50,000 annually are generally exempt from charitable registration, but may voluntarily register.

formation_requirements.certificate_of_formation: Form 202 - Certificate of Formation - Nonprofit Corporation
formation_requirements.notes: Texas requires a registered agent with a physical Texas address. Incorporators may use professional registered agent services.

requirements.due_date_specifics: Due by May 15th each year for all entities regardless of formation date
required_information: Organization's legal name and file number
requirements.notes: Filing is free but required. Failure to file can result in involuntary termination of the corporation.

requirements.filing_agency: Texas Attorney General - Charitable Trusts Section
requirements.due_date_specifics: Before soliciting donations in Texas, if gross receipts exceed $50,000 annually
requirements.notes: Texas does not require annual renewal, but organizations must file Form 802 updates with changes. Organizations under $50,000 gross receipts are exempt from registration.

requirements.requirement_name: Annual Form 802 Filing with Attorney General
requirements.filing_agency: Texas Attorney General - Charitable Trusts Section
requirements.due_date_specifics: Due by May 15th each year (same as SOS filing)
required_information: Updated list of directors and officers
requirements.notes: This is separate from the Secretary of State Form 802. Both must be filed. The AG version must include the IRS Form 990.

requirements.due_date_specifics: File after receiving IRS 501(c) determination letter
requirements.notes: Once approved, exemption does not expire. Organizations receive an exemption number to provide to vendors. Sales tax exemption does not apply to all purchases - review specific exemptions.

requirements.due_date_specifics: File after receiving IRS 501(c) determination letter
requirements.notes: Same application (AP-204) covers both sales tax and franchise tax exemption. Most 501(c)(3) organizations are automatically exempt from franchise tax once registered.

requirements.filing_agency: County Appraisal District (where property is located)
requirements.due_date_specifics: April 30th each year for property owned on January 1st
required_information: Proof of exclusive use for charitable purposes
requirements.notes: Property must be owned by the exempt organization and used exclusively for charitable purposes. Exemption must be applied for annually unless organization receives written notice of approval for future years. Contact your county appraisal district for specific forms and procedures.

requirements.filing_agency: Texas Lottery Commission (for raffles over $50,000) or local authorities
requirements.due_date_specifics: File application at least 30 days before raffle event
requirements.notes: Texas allows qualified nonprofits to conduct up to two raffles per calendar year. Total prizes cannot exceed $50,000 per raffle for most organizations. Organizations existing for at least 3 years may conduct raffles with prizes exceeding $50,000 with proper registration.

requirements.due_date_specifics: Renewed annually from initial registration date
required_information: List of persons with management responsibility
requirements.notes: Required for professional fundraisers who solicit on behalf of charitable organizations. Paid employees of a charity are generally exempt. Bond must be maintained throughout registration period.

requirements.filing_agency: Internal requirement - filed with board and provided to Attorney General upon request
requirements.due_date_specifics: Within 180 days after fiscal year end
requirements.notes: Required for charitable organizations with gross receipts over $1,000,000. Organizations between $250,000-$1,000,000 must have an independent review. Organizations under $250,000 may prepare internal financial statements. Audit must be performed by independent CPA.

special_notes.dual_filing_requirement: Texas nonprofits must file Form 802 with BOTH the Secretary of State and the Attorney General each year. These are separate filings with different requirements.
special_notes.no_renewal_registration: Unlike many states, Texas does not require annual charitable registration renewal. Once registered with the Attorney General, organizations only need to file annual Form 802 updates.
special_notes.board_requirements: Texas nonprofit corporations must have at least three directors. Directors may not receive compensation for their service as directors, but may be reimbursed for reasonable expenses.
special_notes.political_activity_limits: 501(c)(3) organizations in Texas must comply with federal restrictions on political campaign intervention and lobbying activities. Violations can result in loss of tax-exempt status.
special_notes.unrelated_business_income: Texas follows federal UBIT rules. Organizations with unrelated business income over $1,000 must file IRS Form 990-T and may owe franchise tax on that income.
special_notes.dissolution_requirements: Upon dissolution, Texas nonprofits must distribute assets to other 501(c)(3) organizations or to federal, state, or local government for public purposes per Articles of Incorporation.
special_notes.county_variations: Property tax exemption procedures and requirements vary by county. Contact your local county appraisal district for specific requirements and deadlines.
special_notes.gaming_restrictions: Texas has strict gaming laws. Only raffles are permitted for nonprofits, and organizations must meet specific criteria. Bingo requires separate licensing. Most other forms of gambling are prohibited.
special_notes.financial_thresholds: Many Texas nonprofit requirements are threshold-based: $50,000 for charitable registration, $250,000 for financial review, $1,000,000 for audit. Track gross receipts carefully.
special_notes.professional_solicitor_bond: Professional fundraisers must maintain a $10,000 surety bond or irrevocable letter of credit. This protects charities from fraud or misappropriation of funds.
